Lee, open, in the upper end of TL, convex.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We dug two pits on different aspects and decided Hyalite Peak was acceptable for conditions. The new snow seemed to be bonding well with the older/firmer snow.Wind locally redirecting through the drainage, coming from the NE, prevailing winds coming from the SW. Wind loading began around around 1200-1300. Minor cornice growth and minor cornice sloughing. Cornice sloughs only ran about 100' downhill and only affected the top 10-20 cm of new snow.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Gryfja tekin neðarlega í öxlinni í utanverðri Naustahvilft. Rakur snjór undir þurri nýsnævi. Önnur gryfja var tekin ofar í sömu öxlinni í tæplega 500 m hæð sem var mjög svipuð þessari nema gamli snjórinn var ekki rakur heldur samlímdt harðfenni. Það kom einnig brort við 11 högg en ekki slétt og soldil samloðun. Mögulega er þetta veikleiki sem er að myndast og gæti orðið veikt ef það heldur áfram að vera kallt
Crossloading, alpine, close to rocky outcrop.
Crown Profile one day after rider triggered accident. SS-ASu-R3,D2-O. Avalanche was 100' to 300' wide, 18" to 36" deep, 550' vertical. Caught, carried and seriously injured one rider.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: pit dug after snowmobile was stuck, used part of trench. Terrain was only on a 6 degree slope, thus no CT or ECT were complete, but wanted to see the layers in the snow pack. About a half hour later we were on a N face aspect and had a avalanche release. Avi released on a buried near surface faceted crystal layer at 108 cm, which was my layer of concern.

Old crust/facet layers have undergone numerous significant melt/freeze cycles and are now in the frozen state. Very strong. Rounding moist facets still exist from 80cm and below but it would take a huge load to break the K hard crusts above. Or another significant warm up. Much closer to the spring regime than I've seen yet this season.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This is a Highway avalanche path above Highway 550 north of Coal Bank.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: weather - AM we had blustery conditions, rapid loading, poor vis on way up to pass, steady breeze and S1+ until lunch, early afternoon brought breaking skies, rapidly warming temps, intermittent solar, increase in wind. snowpack - storm snow was weak and light density, 3 distinct layers in new/storm snow correspond in distinct lulls in 3 day event, stability tests reveal consistent failure at 143cm, layer of concern

Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Site characteristics: TL feature, planar, rocky slope with sparse trees.
126-125: Visible layer in pit wall. Hard to isolate crystals as they were somewhat amalgamated together and facetting out. Suspect developed on March 7, buried March 10. 120-98: Densely packed facets, variable resistances. Mostly K- 77-78: Did not find this in the initial obs wall. After the first result, checked crystal ID and confirmed DH size 2-6 in this isolated band which seemed attached to an old decomposed crust. No other DH discovered in pit wall.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Graupel layer is easily identifiable and DT22 broke cleanly across this layer. Faceted layer below ice crust in old snow is also easily identifiable but did not form a contiguous layer in this area, it was loose but wet and interspersed with ice chunks suggesting a rough snow surface prior to new snow.

Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Complex upper snowpack. Two separate near-surface faceting processes happening in the upper 40cm. Radiation Recrystallization at the surface with a few hours of off angle sun in the morning and Melt-Layer Recrystallization at 171cm from the wet old snow surface prior to storm on 3/13. Pack is cooling so frozen crust at 171cm will take a larger load and need a bigger thump to activate unless we get another strom warm up.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Th-F was a warm storm. It rained hard in town. Snow level looked to be about 8500'. The result was a thin (<0.5cm) loose layer sitting on a similar thin crust sitting on a layer of 4F hardness PP.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; Instability rapidly rising; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
First day after the heaviest storm of the season for the area: 110+ cm over 48 h. Warming temperature trends. Widespread natural avalanche cycle with large avalanches (sizes 2-4) on all aspects, both loose and slabs, some of which 100 cm deep and running full path.
The location of the profile was chosen as to explore the snowpack in potential trigger zone of avalanches on the easily accessible W-NW slopes of Todorka to Banderitsa chutes and the so called Promise Land.
The results showed that the new snow has been falling at different temperatures and with different intensity and displays TOUCHY slab properties at multiple depths. On top of that, the whole new storm snow (110+) is sitting on top of a hard ice layer.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack was wet and punchy. Localized collapsing around skis. Liquid water is snow to return to solid. Did not descend lower on slope expecting snow to more wet and unstable at lower elevation.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Our aim was to see how the snowpack is developing after 2 significant weather events: rapid warming and the new snowfall of about 20 cm from the previous 24 h. We dug a profile at the same place just a week ago.
Surprisingly the snowpack looks much better than 7 days ago when we dug a profile at that exact location. The concerning layers from the upper and middle part of the snowpack have transformed and rounded.
The only concern is the basal layers which comprise of huge depth hoar crystals with no bonding sitting under a 13 cm crust that is transforming and not so strong anymore.
Although deeper than 1m, at shallower spots this combination might be triggered.

User.name: Nathan Friesen
User.affil: BC Ministry of Transportation North Cascades Avalanche Program

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sled-cutting i liknande små sluttningar gav uppsprickning i 15-20 cm flak men med begränsad sprickutbredning. Större sluttningar skulle troligen producera laviner, step-down är möjligt. FC ner 24 cm har möjligen inslag av SH. FC-lagret ner 22-25 cm är lättast att påverka, men FC ner 44 har mycket god sprickutbredning.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Smal feature, lee, planar, TL
Tilt test revealed shear on stellars down about 10cm; otherwise mostly concerned with weakening snow surfaces on north. Wind skins also breaking down as well.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ALP, normal läsluttning. HS sond+. Hade ackumulerat om det blåst syd där igår. Svårt veta om profilplats är representativ (ffa lagret ner 20-24) då nysnö och flatljus gjorde att det var svårt se gamla snöytan. Grävde 100 m därifrån och hittade samma lager fast mer mot P än 1F.
Moränrygg, lä från gårdagens sydvind, och därför lite mer F - snö på ytan än AVG som är 10.
Íslag í 33cm sem brotnaði í samþjöppunarprófi í tvígang. Virðist einnig vera veikt lag í 110cm. Fann skil í 12cm og 50cm. Snjórinn er mjög jafn og nokkuð þéttur. Rekupróf skilaði engum árangri.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Южный борт

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: *ECTP30 @105.5: Isolated with cord down to 105cm from ground (top of knife+ rain-crust). Isolation in this snowpack is a little tough, and the isolation dimensions where off. At the bottom of the isolated column the width was 30cm on one side, and 22cm on the shovel tap side. We isolated a second ext. column (with proper dimensions) down to the same rain-crust, but could not reproduce a failure in the facet layer above the rain-crust.
